data.title: Cursor is black in dark theme
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise

This happens when you remote into Windows 10 from Mac OS. The cursor is black in color in the dark theme which makes it really hard to see where it is.

data.title: Support In-Document links inside of the markdown editor
data.body:
Fixes #17288

Add support for navigating toc style links in the markdown editor itself:

```md
[text](#section)

# Section
```

data.title: VSCode 1.8.1 ships with insecure node.dll 6.5.0
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:49:23.350Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.2.9200
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install VSCode 1.8.1.
2. Check version of `C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\node.dll`.

See https://nodejs.org/en/blog/release/v6.9.0/

It also causes reports in desktop vulnerability scanners like Secunia PSI. https://secunia.com/vulnerability_scanning/personal/

2. Set Theme to Quiet Light

data.title: Snippet insert expansion is incorrect in some cases
data.body:
VS Code Version - Insiders
OS Version - macOS

```
var fs = require('fs');

fs.readFile
```

Type opening paren `(`

I expect to see 

```
fs.readFile(file, options, callback)
```
 
Instead I see

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/22316059/72d75980-e31f-11e6-8511-74bbd4740056.png)

```
fs.readFile((file), options, callback, err, data)
```

Notice how `err` and `data` are flattened. Also the parens around file don't seem correct. You can see a similar thing when you type `console.log(`

data.title: HTML attributes not properly highlighted
data.body:
Apologies if this isn't the right place, but I'm convinced it's a bug.

I'm seeing really boring HTML formatting in my editor. I just spent like 3 hours trying to figure out what was going on, and I can't find any solution or fix. Hoping someone knows why my HTML formatting looks uninteresting, or any ideas to change it, and I think it might be a bug. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/273842/22315647/eb467322-e31c-11e6-9a51-9c04ea08f0e7.png)

Also, in JSX, block definitions look uninteresting as well. I wouldn't be surprised if this was related.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/273842/22315676/161a3b06-e31d-11e6-9420-8dec09d9fc5f.png)

- VSCode Version: Version 1.8.1 (1.8.1)
- OS Version: `macOS 10.12.2`
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open HTML file.
2. See boring formatting.

data.title: Background color for theme is not applied

Reproes on MacOS and Windows right now

- Switch 'color theme' to "Tomorrow Night Blue" or "Red"
- The editor background color is the same generic dark color, not blue/red

Was this changed on purpose?

data.title: Detect `const arrow function` as function
Should panel toggle keybindings focus instead of toggle when the panel is not active?
data.body:
Currently all the panel toggle commands hide the respective panel when it's visible and show it when it's hidden. I find this annoying though and instead use the following custom keybinding:

```js
{
  "key": "ctrl+`",
  "command": "workbench.action.terminal.focus",
  "when": "!terminalFocus"
}
```

This overrides the setting when the terminal does not have focus to simply focus it, but retain the hide behavior when it is focused. This means you don't have to hit <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>\`</kbd> twice in order to get focus to the terminal when it's already displayed but not focused. This does change the hiding the terminal case when it's not focused to need 2 <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>\`</kbd>'s but personally I hardly ever do this compared to switching focus from the editor to the terminal.

I frequently tell users about my config and they all react positively so I'm wondering whether we should make this the default behavior for *all* panels (to keep them consistent).

/discuss

data.title: VSCode does not like inline CSS
data.body:
We all know inline CSS is a really bad practice and should be avoided at all costs by any web developer. Yeah, right. But VS Code seems to be taking this rather too seriously and applying bad formatting to any HTML after a style attribute in HTML document, shifting every line after the rotten one to the left, therefore messing the indentation completely. ## How to reproduce 1. Open a new VS Code window 2. Set language to HTML (Control+K, M then type HTML) 3. Paste in the following code: ```
I'm a block element

I'm a paragraph

I'm a second paragraph

I'm a third paragraph

``` 4. Format code with Control+Shift+F And it's done! The code will look like this: ```
I'm a block element

I'm a paragraph

I'm a second paragraph

I'm a third paragraph

``` Notice the 3 empty lines and how the `

` tags have shifted leftwards? Tested on version 1.8.1

data.title: Files need to ignore hash/query portion of URIs and only check for fsPath

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9

Repo:

Using an extension, try opening the same file multiple times but using different hash fragments: `file.js#L10`, `file.js#L20`, `file.js#L30`

I believe i used the `vscode.open` command

**Bug**
We open a new document in each case instead of switching to an already open copy.

I also notice multiple entries for the same file in the quick open view:

![screen shot 2017-01-25 at 2 07 28 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/22311397/2d101a8e-e308-11e6-937b-7fadc5a758b8.png)

data.title: "press any key to close the terminal" key is passed on to editor
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19057

Probably an easier way to get this, but -

- Windows, start a task in the terminal
- Press `ctrl+c` in the terminal
- `y` to kill the task
- See "press any key to close the terminal" prompt - press any key
- The terminal closes but also that keypress is typed in the editor

data.title: Feature request: commandline argument to autoexecute debugger with given configuration name

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: For example: `--debug launch`

data.title: workspaces can't override settings for executables
data.body: Removes the ability for workspaces to override settings that specify executables, i.e. marked with 'isExecutable'.

data.title: Fixes Webview reload Flickering
data.body:
Fixes #19351

**Bug**
When refreshing a webview, a slight flicker can sometime be seen. This is especially noticable when using the markdown preview.

**Fix**
Instead of replacing the content of the iframe for refresh, create a new iframe with the new content and do a swap to update.

data.title: Fixes #19194 - Added option to clear Terminal in Terminal Context menu
data.body: Fixes #19194 by adding an option 'Clear' in the Terminal Context Menu to clear the Terminal.

data.title: experimentalDecorators not recognized in vscode
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider fbea777a881523bc01a1358d115b16673dc5942e - OS Version: MacOS Sierra Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create Typescript file with decorators (like [mobx](https://github.com/mobxjs/mobx/)) 2. Enable `experimentalDecorators` in `tsconfig.json` ```json { "compilerOptions": { "experimentalDecorators": true } } ``` Result (reloading vscode doesn't help): Warning still says: ``` [ts] Experimental support for decorators is a feature that is subject to change in a future release. Set the 'experimentalDecorators' option to remove this warning. ```

data.title: Background color not right for themes whose bgcolor is neither black or white
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Insiders dated 2017-01-25
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Change theme to anything which doesnt have a black or white background. Like
- Tomorrow night blue
- Red
- Solarized Dark
- Solarized Light

The foreground colors match between stable and insiders.
But the background color in insiders is only either black or white.

Its black.. or white... feel like breaking into MJ's song here...

data.title: Composed unicode characters break cursor motion

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10

I have the [Noto Color Emoji](https://www.google.com/get/noto/help/emoji/) font installed

Steps to Reproduce:

![animated](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7000710/22303350/371f5730-e333-11e6-81c8-e29f5518b44e.gif)

```
...12345678...
...👨‍❤️‍💋‍👨...
```

Just copy & paste that code in vscode.
That emoji is `U+1F468`, `U+200D`, `U+2764`, `U+FE0F`, `U+200D`, `U+1F48B`, `U+200D`, `U+1F468`
As you can see, I have to hit `→` several times before I can go to the next character.

Electron (or whatever VSCode uses) already handles these characters correctly: if I create a `<div contenteditable>` with VSCode's inspector and I paste that icon there, the arrow keys work correctly.

**Possible solutions**
1. Show that emojy as different characters (CodeMirror does something like this)
2. Make the cursor jump at the end of the composed character with just one hit

data.title: workspacesTrustedToSpecifyExecutables squiggles decoration is not updated when save
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insiders
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add executable related configuration to workspace setting and save
2. The popup window shows immediately.
3. The squiggle will only show after switching tabs. So after the warning message displayed in the popup and click Review Setting to see which one is actually leading to the problem, ppl still have no idea as the inline warning is missing.

 However if you add an unknown setting, the green squiggle shows up the moment you save.
